newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil mulls trade exemptions for Mercosur - report.
newsitem.headline: Brazil mulls trade exemptions for Mercosur - report.

text.p: Brazilian Foreign Minister Luiz Felipe Lampreia said some Mercosur exports may be exempted from Brazil's new import financing restrictions, Agencia Estado news agency reported.
"There is a possibility of exempting some exports from Mercosur countries," Lampreia told reporters at a trade conference in Sao Paulo.
Lampreia said it was too early to say which products could be excluded from the rules, which impose tougher restrictions on importers using financing of 360 days or less.
"We have to look at it case by case," he said.
Brazil's new import rules, announced last week, have drawn fire from trading partners in the Mercosur customs union, which have labeled them "protectionist."
The four-nation Mercosur customs union is made up of Brazil, Argentina, Paraguay and Uruguay. Chile is an associate member.
Argentine Economy Minister Roque Fernndez was scheduled to fly to Brasilia on Tuesday to discuss the matter with Brazilian Finance Minister Pedro Malan.
But Fernndez called off the trip, saying not enough progress had been made in preliminary talks. Fernndez said he might travel to Brazil on Wednesday.
